spocs.title: 6 Ways to Welcome Employees on Their First Day
spocs.excerpt: When the onboarding process is clear, new employees become productive faster, feel secure in their new role, and are more engaged—everybody wins.

spocs.title: Stop the Drop-Bys: How to Master the Work Request
spocs.excerpt: Instead of being subject to anyone who walks by with a “quick question,” follow along to learn how to create a more productive way to file and track work.

spocs.title: What Every New Hire Onboarding Checklist Needs
spocs.excerpt: The first few days at a new job has the potential to be confusing—but a well-organized onboarding experience can help minimize that.

spocs.title: 4 Steps to Reaching Financial Independence
spocs.excerpt: There are times when taking out a personal loan can be an advantageous first step - even if the idea of borrowing makes you uneasy.

spocs.title: A Beginner's Guide to Getting Better With Money
spocs.excerpt: Getting better with money isn't rocket science, but it does require action. If you aren't sure where to start, here are eight important steps.

spocs.title: Automation Is Effective, but Humans Still Have Work to Do
spocs.excerpt: Automation isn’t all roses... Here are some examples from the good, the bad, and the ugly of automation.

recommendations.title: Underpaid and exhausted: the human cost of your Kindle
recommendations.excerpt: In the Chinese city of Hengyang, we find a fatigued, disposable workforce assembling gadgets for Amazon, owned by the world’s richest man.  Five o’clock in the morning and the young woman’s eyelids are drooping.

recommendations.title: China Is Genetically Engineering Monkeys With Brain Disorders
recommendations.excerpt: A visit to a facility in Guangdong province, where researchers are tinkering with monkey brains in order to understand the most severe forms of autism Guoping Feng applied to college the first year that Chinese universities reopened after the Cultural Revolution.

recommendations.title: GitHub Billionaires Will Own More Microsoft Stock Than Its CEO
recommendations.excerpt: Patience has paid off for the founders of GitHub Inc. after Microsoft Corp. agreed to pay $7.5 billion for the coding platform.  The all-stock deal is equivalent to 73.8 million Microsoft shares, based on Monday’s closing price.

recommendations.title: The “marshmallow test” said patience was a key to success. A new replication tells us s’more.
recommendations.excerpt: Here’s some good news: Your fate cannot be determined solely by a test of your ability at age 5 to resist the temptation of one marshmallow for 15 minutes to get two marshmallows.

recommendations.title: A New Golden Age for the Tiki Bar
recommendations.excerpt: Half a century after the tropical craze of the 1960s, the modern age of escapism is taking cues—and inspiration for giant rum drinks—from the past.  There are no TV screens inside the Polynesian, the giant new tiki bar that opened three stories above Times Square over Memorial Day weekend.

recommendations.title: Why a DNA data breach is much worse than a credit card leak
recommendations.excerpt: This week, DNA testing service MyHeritage revealed that hackers had breached 92 million of its accounts.

recommendations.title: Kayla Itsines’ Sweat app will rake in $77 million this year
recommendations.excerpt: In earlier years, fitness gurus would market their programs for getting in shape on VHS tapes and, later, DVDs. These days, it’s an app business.

recommendations.title: Study: honey bees understand nothing
recommendations.excerpt: Zero, zilch, nothing, is a pretty hard concept to understand. Children generally can’t grasp it until kindergarten. And it’s a concept that may not be innate but rather learned through culture and education.

recommendations.title: Save the Scooters, Redesign the Streets, and Save San Francisco
recommendations.excerpt: The scooters have disappeared from San Francisco.  In anticipation of regulations that took effect today, Bird, Lime Bike, and Spin have warehoused their fleets of the shared electric two-wheelers.

recommendations.title: The Fred Rogers documentary Won’t You Be My Neighbor feels radically subversive
recommendations.excerpt: Who among us can resist getting a little verklempt upon hearing the strains of some familiar Mister Rogers’ Neighborhood song? Hum with me:

recommendations.title: My Visit to the World’s First Gym for Your Face
recommendations.excerpt: As a general rule, I try not to open P.R. e-mails. But a few weeks ago I received one that announced the arrival, in New York, of “FACEGYM, the world’s first gym for your face.” Face gym, I said out loud to myself. A gym . . . for . . . my . . . face.

recommendations.title: 5 Pencil and Paper Games to Do When You’re Bored
recommendations.excerpt: In a time before people could cure their boredom by looking down at their phone and immediately retreating into an individual silo of entertainment, slaying its specter was often a cooperative exercise, requiring nothing more than a pencil and paper.

recommendations.title: America’s Largest Private Company Reboots a 153-Year-Old Strategy
recommendations.excerpt: William Wallace Cargill pioneered the modern agricultural trading industry in 1865 when he established a string of grain warehouses across the American Midwest.

recommendations.title: How do Apple’s Screen Time and Google Digital Wellbeing stack up?
recommendations.excerpt: Developer conference season is coming to an end with Apple’s WWDC this week, and the main takeaway is that between Google’s “Digital Wellbeing” and Apple’s “Screen Time,” the two biggest smartphone developers are taking some time to discourage smartphone overuse.

recommendations.title: World Cup 2018: The Boys From the Banlieues
recommendations.excerpt: BONDY, France — Speak to those who saw Kylian Mbappé as a child, who watched him take the first steps in his skyrocket of a career, and they will tell you the same thing: All they needed was one glimpse. That was enough, even then, to know.  When Jean-François Suner, the general manager of A.S.

recommendations.title: Twenty Years Later, Everything Is The Truman Show
recommendations.excerpt: Two decades ago, The Truman Show seemed preposterous. “We would laugh about how unrealistic some of it seemed,” said co-star Laura Linney, remembering conversations the cast and crew would have on the film’s Seaside, Florida set.

recommendations.title: How WeWork became the most hyped startup in the world
recommendations.excerpt: On a Thursday morning in March, a group of young professionals file through the security gates of a co-working space in Moorgate, tapping their membership cards as they enter. Receptionists greet them cheerily, sometimes by name, welcoming them into a large, wood-floored communal lounge.

recommendations.title: Why Aren’t We All Buying Houses on the Internet?
recommendations.excerpt: This article is part of Update or Die, a series from Future Tense about how businesses and other organizations keep up with technological change—and the cost of falling behind.

recommendations.title: Dennis Miller’s new podcast is an incoherent marvel
recommendations.excerpt: The comedic pundit Dennis Miller has racked up an impressive string of failures over the past two-and-a-half decades, from the six-month run of his eponymous talk show to his infamous stint as a commentator for Monday Night Football.

recommendations.title: The Race to Send Robots to Mine the Ocean Floor
recommendations.excerpt: When the 300-foot Maersk Launcher docked in San Diego early Monday morning, it unloaded a cargo of hardened black blobs scooped from the bottom of the sea.
